+++
title = "Medium Access Control Sublayer (chapter 4)"
date = 2019-06-24
+++
<p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">The </span><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Medium Access Control Sublayer</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);"> (MAC) is the layer that is responsible for deciding who can use the communication channel. It’s part of the data link layer. It makes sure that people are not talking over each other.</span></p><p><br></p><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">In any broadcast network, the key issue is how to determine who gets to use the channel when there is competition for it. When only a single channel is available (as is the case with LAN), it is hard to determine the order of who should go.</span></p><p><br></p><h1 id="the-channel-allocation-problem"><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">The channel allocation problem</span></h1><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">The central theme of this chapter is how to allocate a single broadcast channel among competing users. The channel may be anything that connects each user to all other users and any user who makes full use of the channel interferes with other users who also wish to use the channel.</span></p><p><br></p><h3 id="static-channel-allocation"><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Static channel allocation</span></h3><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">The traditional way of allocating a single channel for <span class="ql-formula" data-value="N">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>N</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">N</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span style="margin-right: 0.10903em;" class="mord mathdefault">N</span></span></span></span></span>﻿</span> users is to divide the bandwidth into <span class="ql-formula" data-value="N">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>N</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">N</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span style="margin-right: 0.10903em;" class="mord mathdefault">N</span></span></span></span></span>﻿</span> portions one way. This can be done by splitting the frequency of the channel so that each user has its own frequency band. With only a few users and a steady data stream for each of them this division is simple and efficient. An example of where this is done is FM radio stations. However when the number of uses is large and/or the traffic is bursty this way of allocating falls short. As all users take up a part of the bandwidth they may not necessarily use and which also could be too small to be useful.</span></p><p><br></p><h3 id="dynamic-allocation"><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Dynamic allocation</span></h3><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Some assumptions:</span></p><ol><li><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Independent traffic: traffic from node <span class="ql-formula" data-value="A">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">A</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">A</span></span></span></span></span>﻿</span> is unrelated to that from node <span class="ql-formula" data-value="B">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">B</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span style="margin-right: 0.05017em;" class="mord mathdefault">B</span></span></span></span></span>﻿</span></span></li><li><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Single channel: there is only one channel/link over which communication takes place</span></li><li><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Observable collisions: if two frames collide it can be detected</span></li><li><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Continuous or slotted time</span></li><li><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Carrier sense or no carrier sense: nodes can detect if the channel is in use</span></li></ol><p><br></p><h1 id="multiple-access-protocols"><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Multiple Access Protocols</span></h1><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">A comparison of the various Multiple Access Protocols can be found under Appendix A</span></p><p><br></p><h2 id="aloha-protocol"><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">ALOHA Protocol</span></h2><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">In pure ALOHA, users transmit frames whenever they have data; if a collision occurs, users retry after a random delay. </span></p><p><br></p><h3 id="collisions-in-aloha"><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Collisions in ALOHA</strong></h3><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">The vulnerable period is equal to two times the duration of a transmission. A transmission between two packets can cause multiple collisions. The main limitation of ALOHA is that it is non-scalable, the more devices, the more collisions.</span></p><p><br></p><h3 id="slotted-aloha"><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Slotted ALOHA</strong></h3><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Packets can only be transmitted in certain time slots so multiple collisions can no longer occur. This method is twice as efficient as normal ALOHA. The best utilization that can be achieved is <span class="ql-formula" data-value="\frac{1}{e}">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mi>e</mi></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{1}{e}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.190108em; vertical-align: -0.345em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.845108em;"><span class="" style="top: -2.6550000000000002em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathdefault mtight">e</span></span></span></span><span class="" style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span class="" style="top: -3.394em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.345em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span></span></span>﻿</span>.</span></p><p><br></p><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">On the following image, the messages marked in red have to be re-transmitted:</span></p><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);"><img src="https://i.imgur.com/S6Uo9EP.png" width="328"></span></p><p><br></p><h2 id="carrier-sense-multiple-access-protocols-(csma)"><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Carrier Sense Multiple Access Protocols (CSMA)</span></h2><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Senders detect (sense) if the channel is in use</span></p><p><br></p><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Protocols that apply CSMA:</span></p><ol><li><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);"><span class="ql-formula" data-value="1">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.64444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span></span>﻿</span></strong><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">-persistent</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">: Wait for idle, then send. Often ends in collisions as people will start sending as soon as the network is available</span></li><li><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Non persistent</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">: If busy wait for random amount of time try again. Results in larger delays when sending, but higher channel utilization</span></li><li><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);"><span class="ql-formula" data-value="p">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">p</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.19444em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">p</span></span></span></span></span>﻿</span></strong><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">-persistent</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">: Keeps waiting until free and then sends with probability </span><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);"><span class="ql-formula" data-value="p">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">p</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.19444em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">p</span></span></span></span></span>﻿</span>. Else, wait for next slot </span></li></ol><p><br></p><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">We see that being greedy gives good performance under </span><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">low load</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">. Being generous gives good performance under </span><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">high load</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">.</span></p><p><br></p><h2 id="csma-with-collision-detection-(csma/cd)"><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">CSMA with collision detection (CSMA/CD)</span></h2><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">When a collision is detected we abort (similar to slotted ALOHA). We then have a </span><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">contention period</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);"> to make sure it is safe to send new data. Try and reduce this as much as possible to increase throughput. After this we have an idle period when all stations are quiet (because they have nothing to send). Illustrated here:</span></p><p><br></p><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);"><img src="https://i.imgur.com/4dwuPOF.png" width="550"></span></p><p><br></p><h2 id="collision-free-protocols"><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Collision free protocols</span></h2><h3 id="the-basic-bit-map-protocol"><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">The basic bit-map protocol</span></h3><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">A contention period is split in <span class="ql-formula" data-value="n">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">n</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.43056em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">n</span></span></span></span></span>﻿</span> parts (where <span class="ql-formula" data-value="n">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">n</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.43056em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">n</span></span></span></span></span>﻿</span> is the amount of nodes). Each node sends a <span class="ql-formula" data-value="1">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.64444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span></span>﻿</span> bit during its own slot in the contention period if it wants to send. After that, they begin transmitting frames in numerical order and then repeat.</span></p><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">This thus has 1 bit overhead per device on the network per transmission:</span></p><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);"><img src="https://i.imgur.com/S6zbOOK.png" width="420"></span></p><p><br></p><h3 id="token-ring"><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Token ring</span></h3><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Stations are connected in a circle, which does not need to be physical, can use the same wire. When a station receives a token, it may send a packet and then passes the token to the next station. Similar performance as a bit-map.</span></p><p><br></p><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);"><img src="https://i.imgur.com/UjNMyY2.png" width="334"></span></p><p><br></p><h3 id="binary-countdown"><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Binary countdown</span></h3><p>Binary countdown protocol is used to overcome the overhead 1 bit per binary station. In binary countdown, binary station addresses are used. A station wanting to use the channel broadcast its address as binary bit string starting with the high order bit. All addresses are assumed to be the same length. Here, we will see the example to illustrate the working of the binary countdown.</p><h1 id=""><img src="https://i.imgur.com/cD84spN.png" width="292"></h1><h2 id="wireless-lan"><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Wireless LAN</span></h2><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">We will look at 802.11 (WiFi) specifically. Some notable properties:</span></p><ul><li><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Some stations might not be able to talk to others (</span><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">hidden terminals</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">), because of the limited range.</span></li><li><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Nodes cannot detect collisions while sending (can't talk and listen at the same time).</span></li></ul><p><br></p><p><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Hidden terminal problem: </strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">The hidden terminals may cause a station to not be able to detect a potential competitor</span></p><p><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Exposed terminals: </strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">The exposed terminal problem is when two receivers are out of range of each other yet two transmitters are in range of each other. This will lead to the two transmitters thinking they will interfere with the transmission to the other receiver and waiting to send when in actuality they wouldn't interfere.</span></p><p><br></p><h3 id="multiple-access-with-collision-avoidance-(maca)"><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Multiple Access with Collision Avoidance (MACA)</strong></h3><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Solving the hidden node problem and the exposed node problem. The basic idea behind it is for the sender to stimulate the receiver into outputting a short frame, so stations nearby can detect this transmission and avoid transmitting for the duration of the upcoming (large) data frame. This technique is used instead of carrier sense.</span></p><p><br></p><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">It works the following way: </span></p><ul><li><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">The sender (<span class="ql-formula" data-value="A">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">A</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">A</span></span></span></span></span>﻿</span>) first sends a short Request To Send packet (</span><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">RTS</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">). This is a 30 bytes frame containing the length of the to be sent frame</span></li><li><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);"><span class="ql-formula" data-value="B">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">B</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span style="margin-right: 0.05017em;" class="mord mathdefault">B</span></span></span></span></span>﻿</span> replies with a Clear To Send (</span><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">CTS</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">). If <span class="ql-formula" data-value="A">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">A</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">A</span></span></span></span></span>﻿</span> receives CTS, it begins transmission.</span></li></ul><p><br></p><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Some properties:</span></p><ul><li><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Any station that </span>hears RTS should remain silent to avoid conflict with CTS<span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">.</span></li><li><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Any station that hears CTS, must remain silent until the entire transmission is done.</span></li><li><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Frames contain frame lengths, so that anyone listening knows how long it will take</span></li></ul><p><br></p><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">It can still go wrong, for example if 2 stations send RTS at the same time. In that case, wait a random amount of time and try again.</span></p><p><br></p><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">We'll use this image as illustration.</span></p><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);"><img src="https://i.imgur.com/TPYD0IK.png" width="554" alt="https://i.imgur.com/TPYD0IK.png"></span></p><h1 id="ethernet"><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Ethernet</span></h1><h2 id="classic-ethernet"><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Classic Ethernet</span></h2><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);"><img src="https://i.imgur.com/NBac9fk.png" width="572"></span></p><p><br></p><h3 id="ethernet-frame-format"><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Ethernet frame format</span></h3><p><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Preamble</strong></p><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">The preamble contains the bit pattern <span class="ql-formula" data-value="10101010">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mn>10101010</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10101010</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.64444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord">0</span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord">0</span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord">0</span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord">0</span></span></span></span></span>﻿</span> seven times and ends with the pattern <span class="ql-formula" data-value="10101011">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mn>10101011</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10101011</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.64444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord">0</span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord">0</span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord">0</span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span></span>﻿</span>. That last pattern is called the </span><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">start of the frame </strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">(for 802.3)</span><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);"> </strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">and it tells the receiver when to expect the frame.</span></p><p><br></p><p><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Destination address / source address</strong></p><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">The first bit of the destination is a <span class="ql-formula" data-value="0">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.64444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">0</span></span></span></span></span>﻿</span> for a single device and a <span class="ql-formula" data-value="1">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.64444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span></span>﻿</span> for multiple devices. An address with all <span class="ql-formula" data-value="1">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.64444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span></span>﻿</span>s is for broadcasting (see </span><a href="https://cshub.nl/post/237395352#types-of-transmission-techno\log y" target="_blank" style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">this</a><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">). Addresses are unique, 48 bits, and assigned by IEEE. The first 3 bytes are assigned to a manufacturer (OUI, Organizationally Unique Identifier), the second 3 bytes are to be decided by each manufacturer.</span></p><p><br></p><p><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Type/length field</strong></p><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Next comes the type or length field, depending on whether this is Ethernet or IEEE 802.3. </span></p><p><br></p><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Ethernet uses type to tell the receiver which </span><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">protocol </strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">is contained in the data. Multiple network layer protocols can be in use at the same time on a machine and so it needs to know to which it has to hand the frame, this is thus specified by this type field. </span></p><p><br></p><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">IEEE 802.3 provides the </span><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">length of the data</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);"> instead, because looking inside the frame for length was considered a layering violation. The protocol is transferred within the data using an additional </span><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Logical Link Control (LLC) </strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">layer. The current rule is that any number less than <span class="ql-formula" data-value="0\text{x}600">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mn>0</mn><mtext>x</mtext><mn>600</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0\text{x}600</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.64444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">0</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">x</span></span><span class="mord">6</span><span class="mord">0</span><span class="mord">0</span></span></span></span></span>﻿</span> is interpreted as a length, while any number bigger than <span class="ql-formula" data-value="0\text{x}600">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mn>0</mn><mtext>x</mtext><mn>600</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0\text{x}600</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.64444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">0</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">x</span></span><span class="mord">6</span><span class="mord">0</span><span class="mord">0</span></span></span></span></span>﻿</span> is interpreted as a type. </span></p><p><br></p><p><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Data</strong></p><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Now the data which has a maximum length of 1500 bytes, this was chosen because the receiver had to have the frame in memory and memory was quite expensive at the time.</span></p><p><br></p><p><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Padding</strong></p><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Ethernet requires a minimum length of 64 bytes and the padding field is used if the data is less than that. </span></p><p><br></p><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">This is done to distinguish valid frames from garbage (garbage can happen on the cable whenever collisions occur). More importantly, it is used to prevent a station from completing the transmission of a short frame before the first bit has even reached the far end of the cable where it may collide. Otherwise it could miss a collision and think the data was sent successfully while in actuality it wasn't. We'll illustrate the problem with the figure below</span></p><p><br></p><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);"><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="436"></span></p><ul><li><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">At time <span class="ql-formula" data-value="0">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.64444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">0</span></span></span></span></span>﻿</span>, station <span class="ql-formula" data-value="A">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">A</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">A</span></span></span></span></span>﻿</span>, at one end of the network, sends off a frame. Let us call the propagation time for this frame to reach the other end <span class="ql-formula" data-value="\tau">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>τ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\tau</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.43056em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span style="margin-right: 0.1132em;" class="mord mathdefault">τ</span></span></span></span></span>﻿</span></span></li><li><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Just before the frame gets to the other end (i.e., at time <span class="ql-formula" data-value="\tau-\epsilon">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>τ</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>ϵ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\tau-\epsilon</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.66666em; vertical-align: -0.08333em;"></span><span style="margin-right: 0.1132em;" class="mord mathdefault">τ</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222222222222222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222222222222222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.43056em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">ϵ</span></span></span></span></span>﻿</span>), the most distant station, <span class="ql-formula" data-value="B">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">B</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span style="margin-right: 0.05017em;" class="mord mathdefault">B</span></span></span></span></span>﻿</span>, starts transmitting</span></li><li><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">When <span class="ql-formula" data-value="B">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">B</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span style="margin-right: 0.05017em;" class="mord mathdefault">B</span></span></span></span></span>﻿</span> detects that it is receiving more power than it is putting out, it knows that a collision has occurred, so it aborts its transmission and generates a 48-bit noise burst to warn all other stations. In other words, it jams the ether to make sure the sender does not miss the collision. </span></li><li><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">At about time <span class="ql-formula" data-value="2\tau">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>τ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2\tau</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.64444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span><span style="margin-right: 0.1132em;" class="mord mathdefault">τ</span></span></span></span></span>﻿</span>, the sender sees the noise burst and aborts its transmission, too. It then waits a random time before trying again.</span></li></ul><p><br></p><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">If a station tries to transmit a very short frame, it is conceivable that a collision will occur, but the transmission will have completed before the noise burst gets back to the station at <span class="ql-formula" data-value="2\tau">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>τ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2\tau</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.64444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span><span style="margin-right: 0.1132em;" class="mord mathdefault">τ</span></span></span></span></span>﻿</span>. The sender will then incorrectly conclude that the frame was successfully sent. To prevent this situation from occurring, all frames must take more than <span class="ql-formula" data-value="2\tau">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>τ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2\tau</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.64444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span><span style="margin-right: 0.1132em;" class="mord mathdefault">τ</span></span></span></span></span>﻿</span> to send so that the transmission is still taking place when the noise burst gets back to the sender.</span></p><p><br></p><p><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Checksum</strong></p><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">The final field is a 32-bit CRC checksum just used for error detection and thus to know when to drop the frame.</span></p><p><br></p><h3 id="csma/cd-with-beb"><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">CSMA/CD with BEB</span></h3><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">After <span class="ql-formula" data-value="i">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>i</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">i</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.65952em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">i</span></span></span></span></span>﻿</span> collisions, a random number between <span class="ql-formula" data-value="0">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.64444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">0</span></span></span></span></span>﻿</span> and <span class="ql-formula" data-value="2^{i-1}">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>2</mn><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2^{i-1}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.824664em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">2</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.824664em;"><span class="" style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathdefault mtight">i</span><span class="mbin mtight">−</span><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>﻿</span> slots is skipped. This is called </span><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">binary exponential back-off</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">.</span></p><p><br></p><p><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Channel utilization</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">: being greedy is good with </span><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">low</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);"> load and being generous gives good performance under </span><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">high </strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">load</span></p><p><br></p><h2 id="switched-ethernet"><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Switched Ethernet</span></h2><h3 id="hub"><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Hub</strong></h3><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Ethernet slowly moved away from a single cable architecture towards one were each computer has got it's own dedicated cable running to a central hub. A hub simply connects a cables together as if they were soldered together. Because twisted copper pairs were already the norm for telephone cables the same type of cables were used for Ethernet. </span></p><p><br></p><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">A disadvantage of the hub is that because it is equivalent to one big ethernet cable the maximum capacity does not increase. Due to technology advancing higher capacity was needed.</span></p><p><br></p><h3 id="switched"><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Switched</strong></h3><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">The solution to this increased load was </span><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">switched Ethernet</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">. The heart of this system is a switch which contains a high speed backplane connecting all the ports. From the outside a switch is similar to a hub and has the same advantages of being easy to use. </span></p><p><br></p><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Inside the switch things differ greatly from a hub however. Switches only output frames to ports for which those frames are destined. When a switch port receives an Ethernet frame from a station the switch checks for which address the frame is destined and sends it the corresponding port.</span></p><p><br></p><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Advantages of switches:</span></p><ul><li><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Increases speed of network</span></li><li><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">All connections have different </span><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">collision domains, </strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">thus having no collisions anymore.</span></li><li><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">If the cable of </span><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">full duplex</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">, a station and the switch can send a packet at the same time, no problem, otherwise if </span><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">half duplex</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">, use a regular CSMA protocol.</span></li><li><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">A switch can send multiple frames simultaneously. However since two frames might be sent to the same output port at the same time the switch has to buffer these frames</span></li><li><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">The traffic is isolated, thus making it harder to spy on the network (though encryption is still the preferred way)</span></li></ul><p><br></p><h1 id="802.11-(wifi)"><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">802.11 (WiFi)</span></h1><h2 id="architecture"><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Architecture</span></h2><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);"><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="480"></span></p><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Can be used in 2 different ways:</span></p><ul><li><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Infrastructure mode, </strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">where the client uses an access point to send its packets. Several access points may be connected together, typically by a wired network called a </span><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">distribution system</strong></li><li><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Ad-hoc mode, </strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">a collection of computers that are associated and send frames to each other, this is barely used</span></li></ul><p><br></p><h3 id="protocols"><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Protocols</span></h3><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">The physical layer corresponds fairly well to the OSI physical layer but the data link layer in all the 802 protocols is split into two or more sublayers. In 802.11 the MAC sublayer determines how the channel is allocated. Above it is the Logical Link Control sublayer, whose job it is to hide away (abstract) the difference of the multiple 802 variants. These days LLC is a glue layer that identifies the protocol that is carried within a 802.11 frame.</span></p><p><br></p><h2 id="mac-sub-layer"><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">MAC sub-layer</span></h2><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Radios are nearly always half duplex. This is due to the fact that the receiving signal can easily be a million times weaker than the transmitted signal, so it can't send and receive at the same time. Stations cannot detect collision because you cannot detect the interference, and therefore it relies on ACKs to determine if collision occurred, if no ACK is received we assume the whole frame is lost. This is called </span><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">DCF (Distributed Coordination Function).</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);"> See this example:</span></p><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);"><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="416"></span></p><h3 id="csma/ca"><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">CSMA/CA</strong></h3><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">We use CSMA/CA (which is similar to Ethernet's CSMA/CD), with an exponential back-off and collision avoidance.</span></p><p><br></p><p><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Physical channel sensing</strong></p><ul><li><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Sense if the channel is in use</span></li><li><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">If so wait for idle</span></li></ul><p><br></p><p><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Virtual channel Sensing</strong></p><ul><li><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Frames carry a Network Allocation Vector (</span><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">NAV</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">) which says how long the sequence of which this frame is part will take to complete. The NAV mechanism keeps other stations quiet only until the next acknowledgement</span></li><li><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Wait for end of transmission</span></li><li><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Optionally RTS/CTS is used to prevent terminals from sending frames at the same time as hidden terminals.</span></li><li><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">See the following image (<span class="ql-formula" data-value="D">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">D</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span style="margin-right: 0.02778em;" class="mord mathdefault">D</span></span></span></span></span>﻿</span> is out of range of the RTS, Request To Send):</span></li></ul><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);"><img src="https://i.imgur.com/y15vgW0.png" width="518"></span></p><h3 id=""><br></h3><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">CSMA/CA with physical and virtual sensing is at the core of 802.11 however, there are several other mechanisms that have been developed to go with it. Each of these mechanisms was driven by the needs of real operation, so we will look at them briefly.</span></p><p><br></p><h3 id="unreliability"><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Unreliability</strong></h3><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">In contrast to wired networks wireless networks are unreliable. The use of acknowledgements and retransmissions is of little help if the probability if getting a frame through is small in the first place.</span></p><p><br></p><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">The main strategy that is used to increase a successful transmission is to lower the transmission rate. If too many frames are lost a station can lower its transmission rate on the other side if frames are getting though with no to little loss the transmission rate can be increased. </span></p><p><br></p><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Another strategy to improve the chance of the frame getting through undamaged, is to send shorter frames. The probability of a shorter frame being damaged is a lot lower than that of bigger frames so sometimes it's helpful to send more smaller frames as opposed to fewer large ones. This can be implemented by reducing the maximum size of the message that is accepted from the network layer. </span></p><p><br></p><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Alternatively 802.11 allows frames to be split up in smaller pieces called </span><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">fragments</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);"> each with its own checksum. The fragment size is not fixed and can be set by the AP depending on conditions. The fragments are individually numbered and acknowledged using a </span><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">stop-and-wait protocol</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);"> (i.e., the sender may not transmit fragment <span class="ql-formula" data-value="k+1">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">k+1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.77777em; vertical-align: -0.08333em;"></span><span style="margin-right: 0.03148em;" class="mord mathdefault">k</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222222222222222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222222222222222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.64444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span></span>﻿</span> until it has received the acknowledgement for fragment <span class="ql-formula" data-value="k">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">k</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.69444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span style="margin-right: 0.03148em;" class="mord mathdefault">k</span></span></span></span></span>﻿</span>). Once the channel has been acquired, multiple fragments are sent as a burst. They go one after the other with an acknowledgement (and possibly retransmissions) in between, until either the whole frame has been successfully sent or the transmission time reaches the maximum allowed.</span></p><p><br></p><h3 id="power"><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Power</strong></h3><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Battery life is always an issue with mobile wireless devices. The basic mechanism for saving power builds upon </span><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">beacon frames.</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);"> These are periodic (every ~100 ms) broadcasts by the AP. The frames advertise the presence of the AP to clients and carries some system parameters. </span></p><p><br></p><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Clients can set a power-management bit in frames that they send to the AP to tell it they are entering power-save mode. In this mode, the client can doze and the AP will buffer traffic intended for it. To check for incoming traffic, the client wakes up for every beacon, and checks a traffic map that is sent as part of the beacon. This map tells the client if there is buffered traffic. If so, the client sends a poll message to the AP, which then sends the buffered traffic. The client can then go back to sleep until the next beacon is sent.</span></p><p><br></p><h2 id="wifi-frames"><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Wifi frames</strong></h2><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">802.11 uses 3 different classes of frames: </span><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">data</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">, </span><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">control </strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">and </span><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">management</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">. Each of these has a header with a variety of fields used within the MAC sublayer.</span></p><p><br></p><p><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);"><em><img src="https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/xwIYXyRPDWj0y3Je35TzRqsSzR3fo4ttrO5ooasSgogmv-0xoduwVs2k8nu_yKxTS73NNri7RLRGR3YnRCZCEjJ0Hng_umGPgmIXPgAIbTl6Ea2O7T3nQAVnlWk2b8JeoxjhPJJN" height="204" width="624"></em></strong></p><p><br></p><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Data frame:</span></p><ul><li><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Frame control</strong></li><li class="ql-indent-1"><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Version:</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);"> Version number of the protocol, currently <span class="ql-formula" data-value="00">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mn>00</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">00</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.64444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">0</span><span class="mord">0</span></span></span></span></span>﻿</span></span></li><li class="ql-indent-1"><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Type: </strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Data, control or management. For regular data frames <span class="ql-formula" data-value="10">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.64444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord">0</span></span></span></span></span>﻿</span> </span></li><li class="ql-indent-1"><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Subtype:</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);"> E.g. RTS or CTS. For regular data frames <span class="ql-formula" data-value="0000">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mn>0000</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0000</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.64444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">0</span><span class="mord">0</span><span class="mord">0</span><span class="mord">0</span></span></span></span></span>﻿</span>. See </span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/802.11_Frame_Types" target="_blank" style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">this</a></li><li class="ql-indent-1"><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">To DS/From DS:</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);"> Whether it is going to or from the networks connected to the AP</span></li><li class="ql-indent-1"><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">More frag: </strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">More fragments will follow</span></li><li class="ql-indent-1"><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Retry: </strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">This is a retry from a previous try</span></li><li class="ql-indent-1"><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Pwr mgt:</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);"> Indicates that sender is going into power management mode</span></li><li class="ql-indent-1"><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">More data:</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);"> More frames will follow</span></li><li class="ql-indent-1"><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Protected:</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);"> Data is encrypted</span></li><li class="ql-indent-1"><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Order:</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);"> Tells the receiver that the higher layer expects the frames strictly in order</span></li><li><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Duration: </strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">How long the frame and its ack will occupy the channel (in ms)</span></li><li><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Addresses: </strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">in IEEE 802 format (MAC address)</span></li><li class="ql-indent-1"><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Address 1: The direct recipient (the AP, often)</span></li><li class="ql-indent-1"><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Address 2: The sender</span></li><li class="ql-indent-1"><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Address 3: The final recipient</span></li><li><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Sequence:</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);"> To avoid duplicates, sequence id. 4 bits for the fragment id and 12 that are incremented each transmission.</span></li><li><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Data:</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);"> The next protocol’s data. In the LLC format to detect the protocol.</span></li><li><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Check sequence:</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);"> 32-bit CRC</span></li></ul><p><br></p><p><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Management </strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">frames are similar to data, but contain extra data that depends on the subtype. </span><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Control </strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">frames are short and only have <span class="ql-formula" data-value="1">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.64444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span></span>﻿</span> address and no data. They do have frame control, duration and check sequence fields.</span></p><p><br></p><h2 id="services"><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Services</strong></h2><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">The 802.11 standard defines the services that the clients, the access points, and the network connecting them must be a conformant wireless LAN. These services cluster into several groups:</span></p><ul><li><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Association service:</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);"> For phones to connect to APs</span></li><li><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Reassociation service:</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);"> For phones to change it’s preferred AP</span></li><li><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Disassociation service:</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);"> Phones and AP can stop the connection.</span></li><li><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Authentication service:</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);"> Proof that you are allowed to connect, using WPA2</span></li></ul><p><br></p><ul><li><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Distribution service: </strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Determines how to route packets that arrive at the AP</span></li><li><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Integration service:</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);"> Handles any translation to send a packet over a different protocol</span></li><li><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Transmit power control service:</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);"> Gives station information that it needs to meet regulatory requirements on the power limit</span></li><li><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Dynamic frequency selection:</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);"> To avoid the station from using the 5GHz service when it’s not possible</span></li></ul><p><br></p><h1 id="data-link-layer-switching"><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Data Link Layer Switching</span></h1><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Ethernet switches bridge multiple networks together.</span></p><p><br></p><h2 id="learning-bridges"><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Learning bridges</span></h2><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">A bridge accepts every frame that it receives, and must decide to which networks the frame must be sent. </span></p><p><br></p><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">It uses </span><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">backward learning</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">:</span></p><ul><li><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Create a hashtable of all IP’s and their subnetworks</span></li><li><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Listen on each subnetwork, by looking at the source addresses, they can see which nodes are on which subnetwork</span></li><li><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Store time of last activity with each IP, purge entries that are inactive for a few minutes</span></li><li><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">If we don’t know a certain IP, send it everywhere</span></li></ul><p><br></p><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">The logic:</span></p><ul><li><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">If the destination subnetwork is the same as the source subnetwork, discard the packet</span></li><li><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">If the destination subnetwork is different from the source subnetwork, send the packet there</span></li><li><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">If the destination subnetwork is unknown, send the packet everywhere (flooding)</span></li></ul><p><br></p><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">We can start forwarding as soon as the header has come in, we don’t need to wait for the rest of the packet. This is called </span><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">cut-through switching</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">.</span></p><p><br></p><h2 id="spanning-tree-bridges"><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Spanning tree bridges</span></h2><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">We can create loops in our network to increase redundancy, but this will cause problems with the previous protocol.</span></p><p><br></p><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">We will construct a spanning tree through the network.</span></p><ul><li><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">First, we need a root for the tree. Find the lowest mac address (since mac addresses are unique)</span></li><li><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Next, a shortest path from each node to the root must be constructed. Each node finds out it’s distance to the root, and chooses the smallest distance of it’s connections</span></li><li><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">The algorithm keeps running while the network is running, to adjust for topology changes</span></li></ul><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);"> </span></p><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);"><img src="https://i.imgur.com/gf9GXOO.png" width="451"></span></p><h3 id=""><br></h3><h2 id="repeaters,-hubs,-bridges,-switches,-routers,-and-gateways"><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Repeaters, hubs, bridges, switches, routers, and gateways</span></h2><p><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Repeaters</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">: Get signal from one side, boost and clean it up, then re-send it on the other side. Used to extend maximum cable length.</span></p><p><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Hubs</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">: Repeaters with multiple inputs and outputs.</span></p><p><br></p><p><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Bridge</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">: Connects two or more LANS, creates different collision domains</span></p><p><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Switches</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">: Modern bridges. Pretty much the same thing.</span></p><p><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Routers</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">: Frame headers are stripped off and the network layer is passed to the routing software. &nbsp;Does not see MAC addresses.</span></p><p><br></p><p><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Transport gateways</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">: Used to connect two computers that use different connection-oriented protocols. </span></p><p><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Application gateways</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">: Understands the pure data, and can change it into a different format. For example, SMS to email.</span></p><p><br></p><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);"><img src="https://i.imgur.com/Xx0Hwun.png" width="470"></span></p><p><br></p><h2 id="virtual-lans"><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Virtual LANs</span></h2><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Why does it matter who is on a LAN?</span></p><ul><li><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Security, because some packets may only be intended for certain computers. Letting some servers not be accessible from outside a LAN is a good thing.</span></li><li><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Load, some networks are more loaded than others, in which case it might be useful to separate them.</span></li><li><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Broadcast traffic, as the network size increases, packets that ask questions like “Who owns IP address x?” increase.</span></li></ul><p><br></p><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Creating physical LAN’s for every logical structure is not always possible. Solution: </span><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Virtual LANs</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">.</span></p><ul><li><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Configure the switches such that they know which computer belongs to which VLAN</span></li><li><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Only allow communication between the same “colors” (VLANs are often named after colors). </span></li><li><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Label each port with which colors are accessible via the port, for broadcast traffic, send only to the port which is labeled with the color.</span></li></ul><p><br></p><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);"><img src="https://i.imgur.com/cHwmN51.png" width="436"></span></p><p><br></p><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Packets need to contain which VLAN they belong to, so we keep track of that in the Ethernet header. In the header we add a few fields before the the length field:</span></p><ul><li><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">VLAN protocol id: </strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">always the same value (<span class="ql-formula" data-value="0\text{x}8100">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mn>0</mn><mtext>x</mtext><mn>8100</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0\text{x}8100</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.64444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">0</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">x</span></span><span class="mord">8</span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord">0</span><span class="mord">0</span></span></span></span></span>﻿</span>), and is interpreted as type (2 bytes)</span></li><li><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Pri</strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">: priority, has nothing to do with VLAN, but as we're changing it anyway we add it (3 bits)</span></li><li><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">CFI: </strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">kind of a controversial bit, now not really in use (1 bit)</span></li><li><strong style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">VLAN identifier: </strong><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">specifiying to which VLAN it belongs. <span class="ql-formula" data-value="0\text{x}000">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mn>0</mn><mtext>x</mtext><mn>000</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0\text{x}000</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.64444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">0</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">x</span></span><span class="mord">0</span><span class="mord">0</span><span class="mord">0</span></span></span></span></span>﻿</span> means no VLAN (12 bits)</span></li></ul><p><br></p><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Bridges need to be aware of VLANs to support them, though legacy bridges are still supported. If the bridges are not VLAN aware, we just always send the packets there:</span></p><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);"><img src="https://i.imgur.com/bltrWxi.png" width="429"></span></p><h1 id="appendix-"><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">Appendix </span></h1><h2 id="a"><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);">A</span></h2><p><span style="background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0);"><img src="https://i.imgur.com/bJ7blk1.png" width="419"></span></p>
